content.raw:
I agree, levels can be flexible. They can overlap in their volumes as well as in the entities they contain (one entity can be in multiple levels). [This](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hemu6rlgzkQ) video covers levels pretty well.
We can have the concept of a default level that includes all entities not currently included in a level. This could include ground planes, global lights, heightmaps, etc. If a performer moves out of a level and is not in any other level, it would be considered to be in the default level.

I am not sure we want to automatically define levels because they would be different depending on the application/environment. In a tunnel environment with a limited line of sight, a level can be a small volume. Whereas in an open environment, the level would have to be quite large. Manually defining it would allow the user to optimize for their use case. I do take your point about it being error-prone, but providing good visualization and feedback to the user creating the levels might be easier than automatically creating levels.
